docs.snippet: The star of "Twilight," Robert Pattinson has no special business being at the Oscars, except that his presence on screen or especially in person gives perfectly healthy young women the vapors....
docs.lead_paragraph: Some of you may know that the Academy has booked Robert Pattinson to do some presenting on Sunday night. The star of "Twilight," Mr. Pattinson has no special business being at the Oscars, except that his presence on screen or especially in person gives perfectly healthy young women the vapors. The Bagger spent some quality time watching the intersect between Mr. Pattison and his fan base and he can attest that the Oscar producers just took care of a broad swath of the young teen demographic. Young women would pay big money to watch Mr. Pattinson read the phone book, which is sort of what presenting an Oscar actually is.
docs.abstract: The star of "Twilight," Robert Pattinson has no special business being at the Oscars, except that his presence on screen or especially in person gives perfectly healthy young women the vapors.

headline.main: The Bagger in L.A.: Vampire Love

docs.snippet: Film | Marisa Tomei, up for an Oscar for playing a stripper in "The Wrestler," joins a long line of actresses who won acclaim playing women in the sex trade. "Inherently flawed characters, who possess what some might see as mental, moral or physic...
docs.lead_paragraph: Film | Marisa Tomei, up for an Oscar for playing a stripper in "The Wrestler," joins a long line of actresses who won acclaim playing women in the sex trade: Charlize Theron, Julia Roberts, Nicole Kidman, Kim Basinger, Natalie Portman, Jodie Foster, Elisabeth Shue, Jane Fonda, Greta Garbo -- the list stretches back to the first woman Oscar winner. Why? Such roles are "a natural corollary to another time-tested role, the male criminal. Another reason: Inherently flawed characters, who possess what some might see as mental, moral or physical imperfections, make for more courageous acting performances." Oh, yeah, and then there's sex. [Wall Street Journal]
docs.abstract: Film | Marisa Tomei, up for an Oscar for playing a stripper in "The Wrestler," joins a long line of actresses who won acclaim playing women in the sex trade. docs.snippet: FAIRCHILD--Robert F.,of New York and Quogue died suddenly on February 16th, after enjoying a wonderful weekend fishing on his boat, The Grand Cru. Beloved father of Stephanie and Roger Griswold, Suzie and Bruce Kovner, Samantha and Chris Storkerso...
docs.lead_paragraph: FAIRCHILD--Robert F.,of New York and Quogue died suddenly on February 16th, after enjoying a wonderful weekend fishing on his boat, The Grand Cru. Beloved father of Stephanie and Roger Griswold, Suzie and Bruce Kovner, Samantha and Chris Storkerson, Serena and Tyler Sheldon; cherished grandfather of Caroline, Olivia, Liam, Oscar, Roger, and Margaux. Born and raised in New York City, Bob graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and went to work for the family's firm, Fairchild Publications. Bob joined The House of Burgundy in 1971, and is the President and Chief Executive Officer. In May of 1994, he founded the Maison des Grands Crus, in Santenay, France. On July 16, 1987 in recognition of his efforts on behalf of French wines, Bob was made a Chevalier of the Ordre du Merite Agicole, by the French Parliament. Bob is a member of the Board of Overseers of the University of Pennsylvania School of Veterinary Medicine, and the Board of Trustees of the Avon Old Farms School. A former member of the Board of Governors of the Union League Club of New York, he also belongs to the Leash Club of New York, Bath and Tennis Club of Palm Beach, Quogue Field Club and Quogue Beach Club and the Long Island Wyandanch Club. Family will receive friends on Thursday, 7-9pm and Friday 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Funeral service will be held on Saturday at 10:30am at St. Thomas More, 89th Street (between Madison and Park Avenues). In lieu of flowers, please make donations to The University of Pennsylvania School of Veterinary Medicine or Avon Old Farms School.

docs.lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (NBC) FRIDAY NIGHT LIGHTS The team's new quarterback, J. D. McCoy (Jeremy Sumpter, above right, with D. W. Moffett), becomes a victim of freshman hazing. But all that changes when he wins his first game. Meanwhile Tyra (Adrianne Palicki) and Cash (Zach Roerig) have a wedge shoved between them when a woman shows up and claims that Cash owes her child support. 9 A.M. (CBS) THE DOCTORS Segments look at five shocking reasons for weight gain, how lovers can keep fat off together, getting more sleep and relieving stress.

docs.snippet: THE FALL OF PONTIAC  As part of its reorganization, General Motors plans to rely less on Pontiac, which was successful in the 1980s but recently has weighed down the carmaker. Among its missteps was the introduction of the Aztek, above, named one ...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE FALL OF PONTIAC As part of its reorganization, General Motors plans to rely less on Pontiac, which was successful in the 1980s but recently has weighed down the carmaker. Among its missteps was the introduction of the Aztek, above, named one of the world's ugliest cars. EFFORT TO JUMP-START LENDING In a process known as securitization, bank loans are bundled into securities and sold to investors. But this system is broken, and now the Obama administration is trying to fix it. [A1.]
